ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I had an intensive introduction to advanced calculus and modeling techniques. Topics included advanced differential equations, integrals, nullcline planes, phase lines, vector planes, partial differential equations, and a small amount of linear algebra.
Critical thinking and how to apply math in a bioscience subject.
Calculus 2 Fundamentals as well as its applications in a biological context. Series, linear systems, etc.
How to interpret, analyze differential models of biological topics. Definitely helped my understanding of different types of scientific papers.

- Calc II and its application in the biomedical sciences
- how to analyze scientific readings and model biology with mathematics
Integration skills, understanding mathematical equations to model biological scenarios, calculus 2 skills
Application of calculus in biology
I learned some important mathematical models of biological concepts.
I developed greater skills in math involving biological conditions and their translation into a mathematical equation.
I furthered my calculus knowledge and skills, as well as improving my skills with reading and interpreting scientific articles with complicated mathematical models.
I learned to topics relevant to Calculus 2 or Calculus BC such as integration, series, vectors and applicating my learnings to analyze scientific models.
Quantitative reasoning/calculus and biology in very interesting mathematical applications.

I developed a better understanding of how math is used in science and how to interpret models from journal articles. I also gained a better understanding of topics that I had been introduced to in high school.
I learned the basics of calculus 2 but with biological applications! It was so interesting to learn math and see how these math concepts were applied in biological articles.
Calculus from a biological context, research paper reading skills
mathematical modeling, analyzing scientific papers
I was able to develop my calculus skills and also analyze graphs relating to biological models
I learned how to think through mathematical models.
Techniques of integration and differential equation modeling. It was very nice since we were able to see the applications of the math we were learning!
I gained a greater familiarity with calculus, along with its applications in modeling biological systems
I learned essential calculus concepts in the context of biological models and how to apply manipulations of differential equations to a variety of different scenarios.
I learned calculus 2 material and how to apply mathematical models in a science and biology setting.
I learned how differential equations could be used to model different systems in biology, as well as techniques in mathematical analysis.
I developed interest and experience in how mathematical models can be used to describe and quantify real-world patterns.
Mathematical reasoning
Learned various applications for calculus within biological and related systems, with a great focus on systems of differential equations.

Through this course I learned a lot about how mathematical concepts are applied to various biological settings and what the biological significance various modeling techniques. Overall, it was a very well taught course that not only taught the mathematical skills needed, but also placed emphasis on their impact and application.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I have somewhat of a mixed view of this course. On one hand, the professor and TAs are extremely nice and excellent at engaging with and helping students during office hours. Class lecture sessions directly engage with the types of problems you recieve on the homework assignments, which is very helpful. I also very much want to congratulate the peer tutors for their excellent work. Their help on the homework assignments was invaluable. The course certainly accomplishes the goal of making you pretty strongly versed in calculus techniques in the biosciences, and does so in a way that fosters inclusivity rather than exclusive competition. 

At the same time, I noticed a set of things I think could be improved upon. Perhaps it is because of the pandemic, but I often felt like examination preparation and homework assignments were made more difficult than necessary given the substance of the exams and homework themselves. For example, the integration gateway is only considered passed when only one or two (maximum) minor mistakes is made. Although I can understand why this mode of test would be favored, I feel like this actively contributes far more stress than needed given the nature of the assignment. As someone who feels comfortable with how they did on exams, I still studied for the gateway far more than any of the three midterm examinations. I was thinking this through and feel that a solution might be reached in the following way:
-keeping the three-midterms organization of this semester (this allowed me to focus a ton more on the last few topics, which definitely improved my learning and also reduced stress in a subject I and I know many others get scared about taking)
-reducing the pass threshold for the integration gateway and/or one or more of the following:
 increasing the time from 25  minutes to 30+ minutes
 asking students who do not pass after more than four tests to pass an online course module instead
Strengths: midterm formats and flexibility
Great strength with office hours and assistance available, though some problems were very challenging compared to in class examples.

Perusall was a very good platform, helped me engage with the reading,ask questions, and discuss with others. Lecture was also very engaging and topics were explained well, however sometimes I found I wanted work on the p-set rather than paying attention to class. That's probably just a me problem though

Strengths:
- universal applications to the math material
- clear lectures
- lots of office hours
- exams were resonable
Weaknesses:
- very difficult and time-consuming psets
Amazing course! Highly recommend. Professor is great and very organized. PSETS are difficult and take a lot of time but collaboration is encouraged.
The teaching assistants and Dr. Hall were awesome!!

I very much enjoyed working with Dr. Hall; he was able to take abstract math concepts with differential equations and linear systems and present them in a way that was easy to understand. The only issue I had was that the problem sets were very challenging and hard to translate from the class notes at times.
A strength of this course is the breakout rooms in class as that allowed us to discuss the topics with our peers.

The strengths of this class were the TA office hours, Professor Hall's reliability for questions, assistance, and any other concerns from the students, as well as the student led review sessions.

The only improvement that I would suggest is to be in person. Although the online notes and recorded lessons were very helpful, I learn best in person.

Strengths: Interesting topics, Professor Hall was great, felt supported and lots of resources.
Weakness: Some topics were a little hard to follow when learning them. Some more resources would be nice such as resource sheets for topics or anything beyond just the notes that are created in real time during class.
Professor Hall is an amazing and caring professor. The ULA's were also very helpful. The PSETs were much more challenging than class material.
One strength of the course was the organization of the canvas page that made it very easy to access the resources for the class.

Strengths: Prof  John Hall is absolutely amazing and truly cares for his students. Take any class with him and you won't regret it! He even met up with me during the break day. Nataly, Luba, and Murilo were also awesome ULA's! The people in this class really made the material fun, engaging, and less daunting.

Weaknesses: it was hard to stay engaged sometimes, but given that it was through Zoom, we can't really complain.
Strength: Professor Hall is great at always being open to questions and conversation with anyone passionate about math.

I wished that I could have interacted more with the students but honestly I feel like that was not at the fault of the Professor. I also wish that we could have gone over more calc 1 topics that are applicable to the class before diving straight in. Strengths: incredible Professor, Dr. Hall is very nice and understanding even though the content could be quite difficult. Also the TAs/ULAs were some of the best Ive had
The strength was the professor. The weakness was that we often did not spend a lot of time learning the ins and outs of each math concept in favor of learning the specifics of particular readings.

The strength is the professor and the TAs. They love teaching, they were super supportive and caring. The amount of office hours is also a plus. If you need help, you will get it!

No weaknesses.

This course was taught very well, and the course was nicely organized. No criticisms regarding the material or how it was taught, I think Professor Hall is doing a good job with the course and should keep doing what he's doing. As for improvement, I think the only thing that could be improved is the training of ULAs. All of the ULAs were good and capable, but often times there was a lot of confusion and discrepancies of the answers and questions on the problem sets. So I think it would be good to perhaps provide a bit more training/review for the ULAs and prepare a general answer key for the problem sets to avoid any misunderstandings of the problems.

Professor Hall is a great teacher who is very interested in your acquisition of the material.  He sets you up for success with his different assignments and various review opportunities.  Additionally the Undergraduate Teaching Assistants were wonderful for this course!

This course drew on models from many biological fields, which really helped us understand the value of the techniques we were learning. There was help available nearly every day if you wanted to ask questions about the weekly problem set, which was difficult but pushed our grasp of the concepts discussed in class. In terms of weaknesses, I would have liked to have tried to develop a model of my own (even just a small change to an existing model), using what I learned in the course. Reading about them and having terms explained is one thing, but I think attempting to actually develop one would have given me a deeper understanding of modeling.
The strength is the interesting material and thought-out pace for instruction.  The weakness is the slightly limited amount of non-live resources to complete problem sets.
I really liked the way this course was taught, Professor Hall and all of the teaching staff were extremely helpful and did so much to make sure that I understood the content.

The strength is that the papers we read really connected well to the concepts in class and supplemented my understanding. However, I had difficulty with a lot of the math once we finished the calculus section (ie linear algebra) and had to supplement my learning with outside materials. Additionally, the ULAs were great!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: See above.
There were many office hours offered which was so helpful.
Many office hours and great professor who offered help.
Perusall was good, jamboard also helped. There was enough in class discussion/breakout sessions but not too much.

- break out rooms were helpful 
- office hours helped with engagement
Recordings of lecture and an abundance of office hours allowed to great engagement with the material despite not being in person.

I dont think there was much to improve from Covid, the love virtual lectures with review sessions and practice midterms definitely felt like I had the resources to succeed as long as I put in the work.
This class was online.
The live recorded lectures were great. In addition, the practice exam review sessions/answer explanation videos were very helpful.
Office hours were very convenient and super useful when it came to finishing psets! There weren't any that could be improved!
Recording the lectures was very helpful because I would often watch them over multiple times if I didnt understand a topic and needed help.
No improvements could be done. Professor Hall was very understanding and sensible eith assignments, always aware of the difficulties of this semester.
Everything adapted well for the pandemic. No complaints.

The successful practices were: many office hours providing great flexibility, and lecture recordings posted with clear, corresponding notes in the event that you were unable to attend. In my opinion, breakout rooms were okay, but may have been more productive if we got to choose a consistent group to work with.

Almost all sessions were recorded, and this allowed for review of explanations of important topics. 
What would have been helpful is a reference sheet with hints in case the problem set questions gave trouble.
the recorded lectures were great!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: See above. I certainly would over MATH 115, 120, or one of the other introductory courses. This gives you experience in many different areas of math and in the context of modeling. This type of thing is super helpful for biology students. To put it bluntly, if a student is reading this review and debating about taking this or 115/120 and can prepare for a good deal of work, take this course. It's manageable and will not destroy you.
YES. John Hall is incredible and loves to teach. It is very inspiring and motivating.
Yes, I would especially if they are looking to challenge themselves intellectually and have a strong background in math.

Highly recommend! John Hall is a wonderful professor, extremely engaging and good at explaining topics. The content is very interesting as well. We read 7 scientific papers over the course of the semester, which were very helpful in demonstrating the applications of the kind of math we did in the course.
I would recommend Math 115 over Math 116. I think 116 felt a little bit unorganized and that the math 115 concepts weren't completely covered in it.
Yes! Amazing math course taught by an amazing professor!

Yes!! It is very interesting to see how calculus is applied in biology. Especially as a biochem major, I loved seeing the concepts I've learned through the lens of math. Furthermore, Dr. Hall is amazing at teaching and encouraging.

Yes I would recommend to this class, as I had a very good experience compared to my previous math class. I felt we had a good system to facilitate learning and understanding and Dr. gave us plentiful resources to succeed in his class.

Yes, I would recommend this class to any student interested in the biological sciences. Many research studies incorporate mathematical models to describe their findings, making it pivotal to understand concepts taught in calculus in relation to biology.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in biological application for calculus.
Yes, if your are a bio major and want to learn the math concepts that will be most pertinent to the work you will do.
Yes! Prof. Hall is wonderful and this class introduced me to many different mathematical applications of the life sciences.
I would recommend that someone take this course if they enjoy doing applications in math, otherwise I would just recommend that they take 115
Yes!! Take this class, especially if you're premed or a bio major! The math is relatively not super hard, but you also get to learn interesting linear algebra concepts as well.
Yes! To any pre-med or STEM student who wants to understand more how math is applicable to the sciences.
Yes, the professor was great, and the workload was manageable.
Yes! Professor Hall and all of the ULAs were wonderful at explaining concepts clearly and concisely. The material was very interesting and accessible for students of all mathematical backgrounds.
If they needed some form of calc and I would recommend this course. Especially since I like Dr. Halls teaching style and if anyone can teach you this material its him.
Yes! If youre pre-med and will encounter scientific papers in your future, this class can only help!

Definitely! It's a fun way to explore Math. It is cool to see the applications (don't be afraid cause you don't need bio background at all). There's many resources to succeed and professor Hall will do as much as he can for you to understand the concepts. If it was this good online, can't imagine in person!
I would recommend this course to another student interested in biology

Yes I would, especially if they have an interest in biology. I think looking at calculus with biological applications was extremely interesting and helped me stay engaged with math. So if you're still deciding between Math 115 and Math 116, I would definitely go for Math 116 because the support you get from your peers, Professor Hall, and the ULAs is unparalleled.

Yes.  I thought this course provided me with all the skills Math 115 would have + some.  I enjoyed the readings Professor Hall assigned and my eyes were opened to ways to apply mathematical models which I never saw before.  In showing us real-life applications, Professor Hall helped my understanding of the material ten-fold.
Yes! If you are interested in biology and need differential calculus, this course combines the two extremely well. The techniques you learn will really help you think about processes in a new way.
I only recommend if they need the course to satisfy a Calc II requirement and don't want to do straight math work all the time.  It is like the PHYS 170-171 of intro physics.
Yes, Professor Hall is an outstanding professor.
I would most certainly recommend this course to anybody who is interested in biological sciences and needs to take a math course.
I would recommend this course to another student, though I think it would be most beneficial for people in the biosciences.

I would heavily recommend this course to another student who is interested in the sciences, and specifically biology, and does not want to take a standard math class. This class provides a very interesting and refreshing way of approaching math that allowed me to learn math without feeling completely overwhelmed by purely mathematical concepts.

This course was great! If you're premed/interested in science and choosing between this course and 115, I'd say take 116! Professor Hall is incredible, and it's really cool to see how these advanced mathematical concepts are deeply intertwined with science. A lot of the time I would learn retroactively by understanding the literature before the math, but that strengthened my overall comprehension in the end.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Jamboard, Perusall.
Some discussion/class participation
N/A
Office Hours, review sessions, and recordings of lecture
No other
There were addition all review sessions and office hours.
We had weekly office hours with ULA's and peer tutors.
recorded lecture
Recorded videos
N/a
Lectures were recorded so that we could review the content asynchronously.
no others
Lectures were recorded and there were virtual office hours
In addition to live lecture, there were live review sessions, with everything recorded and stored in a media library for easy review.

Live virtual lecture
Recorded lecture
The class consisted of live virtual lectures that were recorded and posted for later viewing.

extras.title:
MATH 116 01
        Math Models in Biosciences I
